cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
What was the title of Status Quo's first UK No. 1 hit?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
To determine the title of Status Quo's first UK No. 1 hit, I need to recall the history of the band and their chart performances. Status Quo is a British rock band that has had several hits over the years. Their first UK No. 1 single is a significant milestone in their career. 

After reviewing their discography, I remember that their first UK No. 1 hit was "Pictures of Matchstick Men," which was released in 1968. This song is well-known and marked a pivotal moment in their rise to fame.

Answer:
"Pictures of Matchstick Men"

['In 2000, the British rock band Status Quo recorded a version of this song for their album "Famous in the Last Century". They played it on "Top of the Pops" and released it as a single which charted in the UK (No. 83) and Norway (No. 4).\n', 'This is the discography of the British rock band Status Quo. They have released around 100 singles and have spent over 400 weeks in the UK Singles Chart - longer than The Beatles. They are one of the most successful bands of all time in the UK. Their most recent album, "Aquostic II – That\'s a Fact!", was released in 2016.\n', 'Quo is the seventh studio album by Status Quo. Issued in May 1974, it features Francis Rossi, Rick Parfitt, Alan Lancaster and John Coghlan, and reached #2 in the UK. Like its predecessor "Hello!", it consisted entirely of songs written or cowritten by the group. The only guest musicians were Bob Young and Tom Parker, who played harmonica and piano respectively on "Break the Rules".\n', '1+9+8+2 (official title in other sources as 1982), is the fifteenth studio album by the English rock band Status Quo, released on 16 April 1982. It was the first to include new drummer Pete Kircher, who had recently replaced John Coghlan, and also the first to credit keyboard player Andy Bown as a full member of the band; on the previous few releases he had merely been listed as a guest musician although he had long been an integral member in all but name.\n', 'BULLET::::- Status Quo\xa0– "1+9+8+2" UK #1\n']

passages:
In 2000, the British rock band Status Quo recorded a version of this song for their album "Famous in the Last Century". They played it on "Top of the Pops" and released it as a single which charted in the UK (No. 83) and Norway (No. 4).
This is the discography of the British rock band Status Quo. They have released around 100 singles and have spent over 400 weeks in the UK Singles Chart - longer than The Beatles. They are one of the most successful bands of all time in the UK. Their most recent album, "Aquostic II – That's a Fact!", was released in 2016.
Quo is the seventh studio album by Status Quo. Issued in May 1974, it features Francis Rossi, Rick Parfitt, Alan Lancaster and John Coghlan, and reached #2 in the UK. Like its predecessor "Hello!", it consisted entirely of songs written or cowritten by the group. The only guest musicians were Bob Young and Tom Parker, who played harmonica and piano respectively on "Break the Rules".
1+9+8+2 (official title in other sources as 1982), is the fifteenth studio album by the English rock band Status Quo, released on 16 April 1982. It was the first to include new drummer Pete Kircher, who had recently replaced John Coghlan, and also the first to credit keyboard player Andy Bown as a full member of the band; on the previous few releases he had merely been listed as a guest musician although he had long been an integral member in all but name.
BULLET::::- Status Quo – "1+9+8+2" UK #1
